ImageData.LabelName: Tumor is more than 2 mm but not more than 4 mm

OriginalSource.Creator: Terese Winslow
OriginalSource.Comment: Updated skin tone in both skin blocks to FP IV
Added the label "OR" and centered the title in the image
Changed the ulcerated tumor in the right panel to show no ulcer; removed the “Stage IIC Melanoma” label and moved the “Stage IIB Melanoma" label up and over to the right
For left panel, removed brackets and labels down to 2 mm, and the lower bracket and the 5 mm label. For right panel, removed brackets and labels down to 4 mm
Revisions made to image per AJCC 8th edition staging

ContentDescriptions.ContentDescription: Two-panel drawing of stage IIB melanoma; the panel on the left shows a tumor that is more than 2 but not more than 4 millimeters thick, with ulceration (a break in the skin). There is also an inset that shows 2 millimeters is about the size of a new crayon point and 5 millimeters is about the size of a pencil-top eraser. The panel on the right shows a tumor that is more than 4 millimeters thick, without ulceration. There is also an inset that shows 5 millimeters is about the size of a pencil-top eraser. Also shown are the epidermis (outer layer of the skin), the dermis (inner layer of the skin), and the subcutaneous tissue below the dermis.

Two-panel drawing of stage IIB melanoma; the panel on the left shows a tumor that is more than 2 but not more than 4 millimeters thick, with ulceration (a break in the skin). There is also an inset that shows 2 millimeters is about the size of a new crayon point and 5 millimeters is about the size of a pencil-top eraser. The panel on the right shows a tumor that is more than 4 millimeters thick, without ulceration. There is also an inset that shows 5 millimeters is about the size of a pencil-top eraser. Also shown are the epidermis (outer layer of the skin), the dermis (inner layer of the skin), and the subcutaneous tissue below the dermis.

Captions.MediaCaption: Stage IIB melanoma. The tumor is more than 2 but not more than 4 millimeters thick, with ulceration (a break in the skin); OR it is more than 4 millimeters thick, without ulceration. Skin thickness is different on different parts of the body.

Stage IIB melanoma. The tumor is more than 2 but not more than 4 millimeters thick, with ulceration (a break in the skin); OR it is more than 4 millimeters thick, without ulceration. Skin thickness is different on different parts of the body.
